generic.title: Introduction
generic.blocks:
Language Understanding annotation has three levels: 

Domain: Domains are the topic and general intent of the user 

Intent: Intents are generally a combination of the action expressed in a query, but can include additional specification of the format of the answer a user expects 

Slots: slots are the entities or attributes mentioned by the user in a query.

These guidelines are written first for deciding domain annotation, and subsequent intent annotation, and then identifying relevant entity/attribute mentions. While this task is generally for interpreting a single query with no other context, sometimes a given query must be interpreted based on previous utterances, or what is called a session. 


HOW TO USE THESE GUIDELINES:

The examples given in these guidelines exemplify patterns of a domain or intent, and not an exhaustive list. Thus, the examples in the main intents should serve as your guidance for classifying the domain, as well as intent. DO NOT use examples from slots. When certain contexts require different labeling, examples and guidelines are provided such that you can correctly determine the domain and intent in context. Examples for slots explicitly indicate what parts of the query are relevant for labeling, and these examples should not be used as examples to indicate domain. Slots are only relevant once the domain has been determined.

generic.title: Domains
generic.blocks:
Generally, every query is first bucketed into a domain. The domain is generally the topic of the query. This annotation schema is particularly concerned with identifying queries that belong to the following domains. Often, a domain may split on intent. Thus you will use the examples in the intents to determine a query's Domain:

  • Alarm - Requests related to the user's alarms.
  • Calendar - Calendar is anything about personal meetings/appointments, NOT public event (e.g., world cup schedules, seattle event calendar) or generic calendar (e.g., what day is it today, what does fall begin, when is Labor Day).
  • Capture - Requests to ask system to take photos and video.
  • Common - Multi-turn intents apply to all domains in multi-turn conversations.
  • Communication - Requests to make calls, send texts/ IMs, find/add contacts and various other communication-related requests (generally outgoing).
  • Email - User request related to email, but not open email app or go to specific Email website.
  • Events - public event - User requests to book tickets to public events such as concerts, festivals, sports games or comedy shows.
  • Finance - User requests for information about stocks, companies, credit rates, blogs about finance and current financial news.
  • Fitness - Fitness domain is centered around scenarios where users are interacting with their health/fitness-tracking wearables. In most cases, this is centered around Fitbit, but other wearable devices with similar functionality should be included here.
  • Gaming - User requests to select specific Xbox gaming controls (invite X to party, friends lists, creating a party etc.).
  • Homeautomation - Home automation is a domain for controlling devices in your home that are hooked up to a hub. You can control the devices from your phone, or tablet, or directly from the hub (similar to the Amazon Echo). From this hub you can automatically turn on and off devices, increase, decrease or check settings. You can also set, and turn on/off 'scenes' which are preset conditions for multiple devices. Please make sure that only queries having to do with home devices get annotated as home automation. I.e, no queries having to do with cars/engines etc. (no 'turn on engine light'), and no queries having to do with device settings (keyboard, backlight, microphone, web/phone camera).
  • MediaControl - Requests related to music, radio, video and movie, plus media control, e.g., volume control, fast forward, rewind, repeat and pause. If the query only has artist (e.g., adele), media_title (e.g., Cell me maybe) or media_genre (e.g., 'R&B'), and nothing else, it should be Other (web search) domain.
  • Movie Tickets - User requests to buy movie tickets, query ticket prices or modify previous ticket purchases.
  • MyStuff - My stuff is about finding files, attachments and messages-the users' stuff. If the query is at all ambiguous with a general search, then the query should be annotated as web.
  • Note - Note domain is about finding, editing and creating Lists and Notes. These can be on Wunderlist, OneNote, or Evernote.
  • Ondevice - This domain is for controlling the user's device. These include settings, opening and closing apps already on a user's phone, locating a user's device, controlling the ring tone, etc. This domain is not for finding music or apps (see Web = Search domain) or for controlling music or other media (see Media Control Domain). Native Apps: Alarms, Battery Saver, Calculator, Calendar, Camera, Cortana, Data Sense, FM Radio, Games, HERE Drive+, HERE Maps, HERE Transit, Internet Explorer, Maps, Messaging, Office, OneDrive, OneNote, Outlook, Panorama, People, PhotoBeamer, Podcasts. Skype, Smart Shoot, Storage Sense, Store, Video, Wallet. Bing Apps: Food&Drink, Health&Fitness, Sports, Travel
  • Reminder - Reminder domain is about creating, editing, and finding Reminders. Since creating reminders can be easily confused with creating calendar events and note taking, it is very important that the intent to create a reminder is unambiguous.
  • Webnavigation - User requests to navigate to a website, go to a link within major websites or search within a website.
  • Weather - User questions/requests pertaining to weather forecasts.
  • Places - Requests for information about, location of, operating hours, directions, travel time/distance, traffic conditions, etc. about localized places (e.g., businesses, institutions, restaurants, public spaces, addresses).
  • Feedback  -  User requests to submit feedback on Cortana. 
  • Notification -  User requests to turn on or turn off notifications.
  • Moments  -  User requests to get daily updates.
  • Teams -  Requests related to MS Teams App. 
  • Entertainment -  Entertainment is a form of activity that holds the attention and interest of an audience, or gives pleasure and delight. It can be an idea or a task, but is more likely to be one of the activities or events that have developed over thousands of years specifically for the purpose of keeping an audience's attention.
  • Orderfood -  Orderfood is for queries realated to order breakfast, lunck, dinner or any other food requirements.
  • Reservations - User requests to make/find/modify a reservation at a restaurant or the like.
  • Taxi - User requests to book a taxi/Uber or track/modify an existing booking.
  • Translation -  Translation is the communication of the meaning of a source-language text by means of an equivalent target-language text.
  • TV -  TV is for queries about operation on Television.
  • Other - Web - Search engine - user writes a query to search in the Internet. Additionally, all queries with the pattern of 'Ask to ', e.g., 'Ask dash radio to play 70s.' and all senseless queries belong to this domain. Download of programms, opening google/bing (different from Chrome, Chrome is an app), searching for updates/updating, connected to cars control, searching song lyrics, most of 'where is...' cases (see examples), find music are OTHER domain.
  • Other Cortana Skill - User is asking Cortana to take some actions, but it doesn't belong to one of the above skills. For example: Direct reference to Cortana (Cortana is a definite executor), chit chat with Cortana, cases that can go to multiple domains, Alexa and Echo (excluding open Alexa and close Alexa), search trips, translation, phrases how do I, How can I.

generic.title: Slots and Intents
generic.blocks:
Within each domain, we annotate INTENTS and SLOTS

Intents are generally defined as the overall goal of the utterance. For example, if the user says 'show me the weather in Palo Alto for this weekend', the intent of this utterance is to find the weather forecast. In follow up turns for certain tasks, intents are annotated for that specific turn. For example: 

  • User: Remind me to water the plants at 3pm  ( Intent=Create_single_reminder )
  • System response: ... 
  • User: No (Intent=Reject)

In this example, the 'No' should be annotated as 'Reject'. Here the user did not like what was recognized by the system, or they changed their mind about the reminder text or the time trigger.

 Slots are the specific content words within the utterance. For example, in our previous example, Palo Alto is the location for the weather forecast and this weekend is the date. So, for this utterance we have the following annotation:

  • Query:  show me the weather in Palo Alto for this weekend 
  • Domain: Weather
  • Intent: check_weather
  • Slots:  show me the weather in <location>Palo Alto </location> for <date>this weekend </date>

Please note that while lots of domains have similar slots and intents, it is vital that you use the correct slot/intent from the domain that the user is expressing.

generic.title: Multiturn
generic.blocks:
Data are segmented into sessions, which is a collection of queries uttered in succession in a given period of time (we call these queries turns). Some sessions are just a collection of unrelated queries, other times, queries can be related to one another. Sessions can be as short as a single query or as many as the user can issue in the time allowed.

Several domains have a system response that supports multiturn questions, where the interpretation of a query may depend on the query before it. There are two types of multiturn in Cortana: free-from multiturn (Places and Weather) and task-based multiturn (Alarm, Calendar, Communication, and Reminder).

Free-from multiturn

In Places and Weather domains, the user can ask a series of questions and not have to repeat themselves. For example, we may see the following types of turn-pairs in a session: 

  • Turn 1: Help me find burger joints in Seattle
  • Turn 2: What about in Bellevue?

OR 

  • Turn 1: What's the weather in Paris?
  • Turn 2: What about in Bellevue?

Here the user is asking follow-up questions, looking for more information about a place, or trying to filter the results given to them. In these domains, in a follow up turn , a query that may have been Web domain in a first turn, could be considered either Places or Weather because the previous utterance tells you that the user had been asking about a particular domain. 

Note: It is essential that you do not annotate in a 'look ahead' manner. We have to mimic the information available to models at the time a query is issued; thus you can only use information provided in previous turns. The following sessions are annotated differently, even if the end result the user wanted is the same. 

  • Session Example 1: 
    • Turn 1:  Home Depot   -> Web,other
    • Turn 2:   Get directions to Home Depot  -> Places,get_directions
  • Session Example 2
    • Turn 1: Get directions  -> Places, get_directions
    • Turn 2:   Home Depot  -> Places,get_directions

Notice in Session Example 2 the intent 'carries over'. In the case that the second query is further specifying the entities the user wants, but they still seem to have the same intent (e.g., getting directions), then the intent of the previous query is maintained until it is clear that the user intends something else. There are similar, but somewhat alternate rules for the other type of multiturn.

Task-based/On rails multiturn

Other domains, such as Alarm, Calendar, Communication and Reminder, only certain intents are multiturn. In these domains, particularly around the creation intents, Cortana helps guide the user when creating a new instance of an alarm, calendar event, text, email or reminder. In these cases, Cortana will ask the user for the values she needs to complete the event, as well as ask the user for confirmation that what she has is correct. 

These can range from two turns (creation, followed by confirmation), or can be up to seven turns, depending on how much the user needs to change. Here are two examples. 

  • Session Example 3
    • Turn 1: Wake  me up at 7:15 am  -> alarm, set_alarm
    • Turn 2: Yes  -> alarm, confirm
  • Session Example 3
    • Turn 1: Remind me to bring headphones to class  -> reminder,create_single_reminder
    • Turn 2: 8 am tomorrow  -> reminder,create_single_reminder
    • Turn 3: No  -> reminder,reject
    • Turn 4: The time  -> reminder,create_single_reminder
    • Turn 5: 7 am tomorrow  -> reminder,create_single_reminder
    • Turn 6: Yes  -> reminder, confirm

Notice that in Session Examples 3 and 4 above that not all intents 'carry over' like in Places or Weather, however all the queries are all labeled as Reminder domain. In certain cases, like when the user is rejecting, confirming or canceling their task, we must identify this intent separately but they are all part of the reminder task. More is discussed in each relevant section. 

In summary, the task of the LU annotator is to first determine the domain, specifically in the user's first turn. If the user is in a multiturn session, then the LU annotation needs to reflect both the domain and current intent of the user. Some intents need to be evaluated on a turn by turn basis. The guidelines below cover how to determine the Domain, Intent and Slots of a given query. In some cases, contextual intent annotation is discussed for particular scenarios where this is relevant.

generic.title: Domain/Intent Annotation
generic.blocks:
The importance of carrier phrases in first turn turn vs. follow up turns  

Carrier phrases are parts of the utterance that clarify what the user wants to do. You may find lots of instances in the data that you are annotating of utterances without carrier phrases, or where the request could be categorized in multiple domains. 

First Turn: carrier phrase example: 

  • Text mom I will be home for dinner.   <-   communication, send_text

Example without carrier phrase: 

  • I will be home for dinner.   <-    web, other

Out of context (i.e., first-turn), this should not be annotated as a text message. Only when it is unambiguous that the user wants a particular workflow (i.e., domain), that requests should be categorized into a domain. 


Follow up turns 

This is not true necessarily in multi turn (or follow up turns) data. Not all users say all slots in a single shot; in the create or set intents, often the user will trigger the domain in the first turn and fill in the slots with the assistance of the device. So in a follow up turn, the text below should be annotated in the same domain (interpretation as the text message). 

Multi-Turn: 

  • Turn 1: Send a text to mom  <-  communication, send_text
  • System Response: What do you like to say?
  • Turn 2: I will be home for dinner  <-  communication,send_text

You may or may not have the actual system response. But you can tell from the first turn that the user is adding the message text since it was not said on the first turn.

generic.title: First Turn
generic.blocks:
Domains that have creation intents (Alarm, Calendar, Note, Reminder) the user has to be very specific about domain they want. For example:

  • Turn 1: Pick up milk on Thursday

This could be a text of a note, reminder, calendar entry or even text. When utterances like this are unclear, and could be part of a number of domains, please label as web. 

Domains without creation intents (Weather, Places, Mystuff) do not need such explicit triggers or carrier phrases. Some intents allow for a weather interpretation although the user did not explicitly ask about the weather, places or their files. In these cases, the triggers can be very subtle: 

  • Do I need a jacket tomorrow <- weather, question_weather
  • Gas stations  <- places, find_place
  • Photos from birthday party  <-  mystuff, find_my_stuff

However, there are still some guidelines about how broadly you can interpret thse domains. Specifics about these domains and their triggers are explained further in each domain section below. 

Exceptional Cases for Annotation

In some domains there are particular rules for annotations that could be considered exceptional and require a specific annotations.

  • Communication Domain vs. Web:
    • Sometimes the user is responding to an incoming notification, in a context-free position (first turn). In these cases, please adhere to the following rules. 
      • Call back/Redial <-  Communication
      • Reply/Send/Send it  <- Communication
      • Read it <- Web
      • Lync play voicemail <- Communication
  • Calendar Domain vs. Web:
    • Questions about celebrity birthdays, general questions about holidays should be interpreted as web searches and not searches on the user's personal calendar. 
      • When is Mary's birthday?  <- Communication/Find_contact
      • When is Will Smiths birthday?  <- Web
      • What appointments do I have on Memorial Day?  <-   Calendar
      • When is Memorial Day? <-   Web
    • Questions about flights are also not considered calendar searches (unless the user specifically requests the search to be on the calendar). 
      • When is my next flight in my calendar?  <-  Calendar
      • When is my next flight?  <- Web
  • Places Domain vs. Web:
    • In some cases, there's a particular scenario that is triggered by a specific utterance. This is a particular example in for Places domain:
      • I am hungry  <- Places

generic.title: Slot Annotation
generic.blocks:
Annotate completely what appears in the query

  • Please label all the slots relevant to that domain
  • Do not add or change text 
  •  Do not attempt to correct spelling mistakes or transcription errors
  • Example: 
    • play a song by The Rolling Stones 
      • Slots: media_person = The Rolling Stones
    • find fish cafe in Kirkland
      • Slots: place_name = fish cafe, absolute_location = Kirkland

In the cases that users hesitate, repeat themselves, or correct themselves inline, it is still important to tag any slot mention. You should not leave some mentions slotted and some not; ranking importance of which instance of the slot is the right instance is out of scope of this form of annotation. 

  • Example: 
    • Set an alarm for 7 7 am 
      • Slots: start_time = 7, start_time = 7 am
    • Call Julie ah Julia
      • Slots: contact_name = Julie, contact_name = Julia

You should tag each instance (mention) of '7am', and both 'Julie' and 'Julia'. 


Only label slot values 

When labeling phrases like 'find a restaurant in Seattle' only include the value of the slot. While we generally exclude any words that originally triggered the intent, there are always exceptions 

  • Example: 
    • open quiet hours settings
      • Slots:  setting_type = quiet hours  <- no tag on 'settings'  
  • Example:
    • find a place with Chinese cuisine
      • Slots:  cuisine = Chinese  <- no tag on 'place'

  

Articles and Prepositions are Outside Content Slots

Don't put articles/prepositions in slots except where necessary! Generally, function words and prepositions (e.g., the/a/that/his/about) should be excluded, except where they are necessary to the meaning of the slot. 

  • Example: 
    • find a restaurant in Seattle
      • Slots: place_type = restaurant, absolute_location = Seattle  <- do not include 'in'

Some function words have their own slot, and should be annotated. 

  • Example: 
    • find a restaurant in Seattle that is near me
      • Slots: place_type = restaurant, absolute_location = Seattle, nearby = near 

This does not apply to temporal annotations. For many time and date phrases, prepositions can alter the interpretation of the time. More is discussed in the section specifically for time/date annotation. Here are a couple of examples. 

  • Check the weather for Saturday
    • Slots:  date_range = Saturday
  • Check the weather for next Saturday
    • Slots:  date_range = next Saturday <- 'next' changes the meaning here
  • Make a reservation for Saturday
    • Slots:  date = Saturday
  • Make a reservation for two in 2 days time
    • Slots: date = in 2 days <- this is ambiguous, so keep the phrase


One or two slots?

Generally, multiple entity mentions (places, people, times) should be usually be annotated as two separate slots

  • Set up a meeting called sync up with Jack Jones and Mary Peterson
    • Slots: contact_name = Jack Jones, contact_name = Mary Peterson

Exceptions to this rule can come in Communication domain. If a contact pair can be interpret as a single contact entry, annotate as one slot.

  • Call mom and dad
    • Slots:  relationship_name = mom and dad 

However, we don't break up absolute locations when it's a single place reference, like 'Gary Indiana' or addresses. We do not break up things in terms of street numbers, cities and countries, or intersections (e.g., 'Shops at the corner of Belmont and Pine'). 

  • directions from chicago to gary Indiana
    • Slots: from_absolute_location = Chicago, absolute_location = gary indiana
  • Where is 221b Baker St in London
    • Slots:  absolute_location = 221b Baker St in London

Again, time is slightly different. If two start_times that refer to the same thing, or a location is broken by a simple preposition like 'at' or 'in' these values should be annotated as one slot, as shown here. Generally, the information is redundant (if these are not contiguous, however, they are tagged individually).

  • set a meeting for this morning at 8
    • Slots: start_time = this morning at 8

  

Do not nest labels inside one another

Do not annotate any items twice, nest any annotations or break up phrases that should go together. Once a word or phrase from an utterance has been annotated, don't put it in any other slot. 

  • Example: Find Boondocks Restaurant
    • <place_name> Boondocks Restaurant </place_name> <- 'Restaurant' is part of the restaurant's name, and not annotated as place_ type
    • NOT: <place_name> Boondocks <place_type> Restaurant <place_type></place_name>
  • Example: find a family friendly restaurant
    • <atmosphere>family friendly</atmosphere> 
    • NOT: <place_type>family</place_type> <atmosphere>friendly</atmosphere>

  

Punctuation

Wherever practical we should not include punctuation in a slot tag. There will be exceptions when it is included in a place name, is in the middle of a tag or is part of a time slot etc.

  • How to annotate ('s) in the data:
    • Generally, possessives should be kept outside the slot, when it can. Possesives should be included in the in cases where the ('s) is part of a proper name, you must include it in the slot:
      • Examples: Directions to <place_name> McDonald's </place_name> in <absolute_location> Springfield </absolute_location>
    • However, if it is not part of a company name or decade, the apostrophe must be left out of the slot:
      • Show me <date_range>Monday</date_range> 's weather
      • Find <contact_name>john</contact_name> 's number
    • If punctuation occurs in the middle of a string that should be only one slot, then the punctuation should be included (do not split the slot):
      • Set a reminder for <start_date>thursday's at 8 p.m.</start_date>
      • Remind me on <start_date> Friday</start_date> to <reminder_text> go to St. Judes for Joes's wedding </reminder_text>
  • How to annotate (.) in the data:
    • Generally, periods (or full stops) and commas, should be left outside the slot where possible
      • <start_time> 10 a.m. </start_time> <- Keep the punctuation (a.m.) in the slot tag.
      • <message> Tell mom I love you <message> . <- Leave the punctuation (.) out 
      • <absolute_location> Baker St </absolute_location> .  <- Leave the punctuation (.) out of the slot tag.
  • How to annotate (?) and (!) in the data:
    • If you see ? or ! in an utterance where it makes sense for them to be there i.e. a message, reminder_text, notes etc. then it is OK to include them in the slot tag. 
      •  <message> Hey Joe that concert last night was awesome! </message> <- keep (!) in the message slot.
      • <message> What time is dinner tonight? </message> <-  keep (?) in the message slot.
      • Remind me at 6 pm <reminder_text> did Joe pick up dinner? </message> <- keep (?) in the reminder text slot.
      • Is it going to rain <date_range> tomorrow </date_range> ? <- DO NOT keep (?) in the date_range slot. 

ABOVE ALL, BE CONSISTENT - IDENTICAL PHRASES IN IDENTICAL CONTEXTS SHOULD ALWAYS BE ANNOTATED THE SAME

If you are unsure about how something should be annotated - please ask, and we will clarify the guidelines if need be or provide more context as to where the data came from. At the very least, please choose one way of annotating, and let us know how you chose to annotate.

generic.title: Time-Date Tagging
generic.blocks:
We make a distinction between dates and times. 

  • Date 
    • Anything a day or longer 
    • Date examples: 
      • Today
      • tomorrow
      • day after tomorrow
      • June 18th
      • The 18th
      • June 18th 2013
      • Tuesday
      • Friday
      • this Tuesday
      • next Tuesday
      • next week Tuesday
      • Thursday next week
      • Two weeks from now
      • A year from today
      • Yesterday
      • 12 months
  •  Time
    • Anything shorter than a day
    •  Time examples:  
      • Morning
      • Afternoon
      • Evening
      • Mid-night
      • now
      • right now
      • 8 am
      • 5 pm
      • lunch time

Make sure to include demonstratives and other modifiers like next, this, this coming, previous as they can change the reference of the time or date to which someone is referring. 

  • Example: 
    • Add vacation on my calendar for this Monday
      • Add vacation on my calendar for <start_date> this Monday </start_date> 
    • Add vacation on my calendar for next Monday 
      • Add vacation on my calendar for <start_date> next Monday </start_date>

  

General Time-Date Annotation

  • We annotate dates and times separately
    • Example: Schedule a meeting for Tuesday at 3pm
      • Schedule a meeting for <start_date> Tuesday </ start_date> at  <start_time> 3pm </start_time>
  • If there are multiple words that refer to the same date or time, they should be kept in one slot. For example, 'afternoon' and '3' are the same tag value, and refer to the same 'time'.
    • Example: Schedule a meeting for Tuesday afternoon at 3
      • Schedule a meeting for <start_date> Tuesday </ start_date>  <start_time> afternoon at 3 </start_time>
  • Sometimes the time expression is broken across a date. In this case, the annotation is separated. 
    • Example: Create a reminder for 8 am tomorrow morning
      • Create a reminder for <start_time> 8 am </ start_time>  <start_date> tomorrow </start_date> </start_time> morning </start_time>
  • Multiple date or time mentions that are different dates or times, should be annotated separately. For example, 'Monday' and 'Friday' are different days.
    • Example: Set an alarm for Monday and Friday
      • Set an alarm for <start_date> Monday </ start_date> and  <start_date> Friday </start_date>
  • In the following example, 'morning', 'afternoon' and 'night' are different times. Therefore they must be annotated separately. 
    • Example: Remind me to drink more water in the morning, afternoon and evening
      • Remind me to drink more water in the <start_time> morning </start_time>, <start_time> afternoon </start_time> and <start_time> evening </start_time>
  • The words 'next', 'current' and 'right now' should be annotated as times when appropriate (i.e., when not modifying a date). Note that only now is annotated in right now. 
    • Example: What do I have right now
      • What do I have right <start_time> now </start_time>
    • Example: What do I have next
      • What do I have <start_time> next </start_time>
    • Example: What is the current temperature
      • What is the <time> current </time> temperature

  

Prepositions and ordinals in time/date slots

Prepositions and ordinals should almost always be included in date and time slots. 

  • Find slide deck Gina sent me <start_date> last week </start_date> 
  • Find the email I send rob <start_date> after January 1st  </start_date>  
  • Wake me up <start_time>in 30 minutes </start_time> 

The only exceptions are for/at/from and between, or other prepositions/expressions that express a date or time range. In cases where domains have both a start_date, start_time and an end_date, end_time tag, these are used to capture the span

  •  Show me the docs I worked on between <start_date>yesterday </start_date> and <end_date> today </end_date> 
  • Set a meeting for <start_date> Monday  </start_date>

note that from should be included if it contributes to the time's interpretation

  • Set a meeting <start_time>3 minutes from now </start_time>

  

Duration vs Start/End 

Events can occur for a period of time. This should not be confused with start/end dates. The use of the prepositions in and for can affect the interpretation of the time mention, where for usually, BUT NOT always, implies duration. Duration is really only appropriate for snooze, timers, and expressing the length of a meeting time. 

  • Example (Start Time):  Remind me in an hour to put clothes in the dryer
    • remind me <start_time> in an hour </start_time> to  <reminder_text> put clothes in dryer </reminder_text> 
  • Example (Duration): Set a half hour sync with Dan 
    • set a <duration> half hour </duration> sync with Dan

Note: Sometimes something appears like a duration, but it should be annotated as start_time:

  • Example: Schedule a meeting in the next hour
    • Schedule a meeting <start_time> in the next hour </start_time> 
  • Example: Set an alarm for 30 minutes
    • Set an alarm for <start_time> 30 minutes </start_time> 

Only use duration if at all points during the time frame mentioned the event is occurring.

  • Examples: 
    • I want to run for an hour = duration  <- I want to run a whole hour
    • I want to run in an hour = start_time <- I want to start running within the hour
    •  Snooze the alarm for 10 minutes = duration <-  I want the alarm to snooze for 10 minutes

The duration tag is explicitly for time duration, not date ranges or time ranges. In the case that there is explicit reference to a start and end time, DO NOT use duration, but rather start or end date (or time).

  • Example:  Schedule a meeting from 1 to 2
    • Schedule a meeting from <start_time>1</start_time> to <end_time>2</end_time>
  • Example: Set a timer for a half an hour from now
    • set a timer for a <start_time> half an hour from now</start_time>
  • Example: Add vacation on my calendar for Monday to Friday
    • Add vacation on my calendar for <start_date>Monday</start_date> to <end_date>Friday</end_date>
  • Example: set a reminder for a week at noon to go to the gym
    • set a reminder for a <start_date> week </start_date> at  <start_time> noon </start_time> to go to the gym

Be sure to mark start and end date when one is mentioned. 

  • Example: Set an alarm Monday through Friday at 2pm every week.
    • Set an alarm <start_date> Monday </start_date> through  <end_date> Friday </end_date> at <start_time> 2pm </start_time>  <start_date> every week </start_date>
  • Example: Set an alarm Monday to Friday
    • Set an alarm <start_date> Monday </start_date> to <end_date> Friday </end_date> 

Sometimes with recurring dates, a date-range is specified. These are not annotated as duration due to the fact that the actual event does not occupy the whole time of that span. 

  • Example: Remind me to run every Monday at 6 for the month of April
    • Remind me to run <start_date> every Monday </start_date> at <start_time> 6 </ start_time> for the <start_date> month of April</start_date>

The interpretation here is that you are not running for a whole month. Rather you're repeating the reminder for the month.

Although rare, sometimes people express exceptions to date spans. In these cases, annotate the whole thing as either date or time, depending on the expression.

  • Example: Set a weekly reminder to go jogging at 4pm every day but Sunday
    • Set a <start_date> weekly </start_date> to go jogging at <start_time> 4pm </start_time> <start_date> every day but Sunday </start_date>


Recurring Dates/Times

For recurring dates or times that reoccur across days (e.g., 6am everyday), contiguous recurring date+time should be annotated separately as start_date and start_time. 

  • Example:  Schedule a meeting for every Monday at noon 
    • Schedule a meeting for <start_date> every Monday </start_date> at <start_time> noon </start_time>
  • Example:  Every Monday schedule a meeting at noon 
    • <start_date> Every Monday </start_date> schedule a meeting at <start_time>noon<start_time>

For recurring times include the every in the <start_time> slot:

  • Example:   Remind me every 10 minutes to get up and stretch my legs
    • Remind me <start_time> every 10 minutes </start_time> to get up and stretch my legs
  • Example:  Remind me every night to make coffee
    • Remind me <start_time> every night </start_time> to make coffee

Times should always be annotated as time. For example, even though the following two examples have the same meaning, they do not have the same annotation because they differ in surface form.

  • Example:   Wake me up every morning at 5am 

Wake me up <start_time> every morning at 5am </start_time> 

  • Example:  Wake me up everyday at 5am 
    • Wake me up <start_date> everyday </start_date> at <start_time> 5am </start_time> 

For recurring dates that have start and end times, annotate similarly to non-recurring start + end times and dates. 

  • Example:   Wake me up every morning at 5am 
    • Wake me up <start_time> every morning at 5am </start_time> 
  • Example(non-recurring): Put carpool on my calendar from 7am to 8am on Friday
    • Put carpool on my calendar from <start_time> 7am </start_time> to <end_time> 8am </end_time> on <start_date> Friday </start_date>
  • Example (recurring): Put carpool on my calendar from 7am to 8am on Fridays
    • Put carpool on my calendar from <start_time> 7am </start_time> to <end_time> 8am </end_time> on <start_date> Fridays </start_date>

If there are multiple days mentioned, but only one 'every', include the 'every' in one of the start date tag, and tag dates independently. Always annotate different days and times separately.

  • Example:  remind me to water the plants every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday
    • remind me to water the plants <start_date> every Monday </start_date>, <start_date> Wednesday </start_date>, and <start_date> Saturday </start_date>


Other Temporal Expressions (non-reference)

Time expression like my week/my day are not tagged as dates/times, even when they appear contiguously with another time/date.

  • Example:  remind me to water the plants every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday

remind me to water the plants <start_date> every Monday </start_date>, <start_date> Wednesday </start_date>, and <start_date> Saturday </start_date>

  • Example: How is my day today? 
    • How is (NO TAG) my day (NO TAG) <start_date> today </start_date>

Note: DO NOT include 'my' in the tag when it modifies another noun. 

  • Example: change my afternoon meeting today to tomorrow 
    • change my <start_time> afternoon </start_time> meeting <original_start_date> today </original_start_date> to <start_date>tomorrow</start_date>

domains.domainDescription:
This domain is for controlling the user's device. These include settings, opening and closing apps already on a user's phone, locating a user's device, controlling the ring tone, etc. This domain is not for finding music or apps (see Web = Search domain) or for controlling music or other media (see Media Control Domain). Native Apps: Alarms, Battery Saver, Calculator, Calendar, Camera, Cortana, Data Sense, FM Radio, Games, HERE Drive+, HERE Maps, HERE Transit, Internet Explorer, Maps, Messaging, Office, OneDrive, OneNote, Outlook, Panorama, People, PhotoBeamer, Podcasts. Skype, Smart Shoot, Storage Sense, Store, Video, Wallet. Bing Apps: Food&Drink, Health&Fitness, Sports, Travel

 This domain is also for users to call Amazon Alexa service from Cortana devices, they can use this domain to open Alexa service (open Alexa)or ask Alexa to do somthing (Ask Alexa to...)or would like to talk to Alexa about their requirements(talk to Alexa/ speak to Alexa).

Scenario: 

User: Hey Cortana, learn my voice.

Cortana: Who voice I am learning? Hua, Peter or John.  

User: Hua < --  "contact_name" slot

Cortana: Okay, Hua, I want to get it right, how do you say your name?

User: "Hua" <-  " training_namepronunciation" slot

Cortana: Alright, your name is pronounced "Hua", is that right?

The model has training_phrase1, training_phrase2, training_phrase3, training_phrase4 and training_phrase5 slots.

intents.description:
Find local or public events, can use some filter words to set constraints on the event type, location, date/time or performers.

Please distinguish the shows happening in local places or on TV.  We don't want to include any TV shows in the events domain, but movies can be included if the user intents to go to watch a film in some movie theater - the intent is to explore and go out to attend the event in person, not watching shows on TV or online streaming.

ONLY if the query implies location/places related to the event/show, it should be annotated as events domain.

But if it implies something showing on tv/radio/online streaming, or we cannot actually tell, it should go to mediacontrol or other domain.

Words like "show" and "shows" are tricky, if we cannot tell if there's location related, we should annotate as medialcontrol domain with proper intent there.

domains.domainDescription: Home automation is a domain for controlling devices in your home that are hooked up to a hub. You can control the devices from your phone, or tablet, or directly from the hub (similar to the Amazon Echo).  From this hub you can automatically turn on and off devices, increase, decrease or check settings. You can also set, and turn on/off 'scenes' which are preset conditions for multiple devices. Please make sure that only queries having to do with home devices get annotated as home automation. I.e, no queries having to do with cars/engines etc. (no 'turn on engine light'), and no queries having to do with device settings (keyboard, backlight, microphone, web/phone camera).

intents.description: (does not include 'turn on')  - User wants to set the device to a particular setting, scene, mode or type. Single mentions of a device + reference to a home automation app/hub should be annotated as home automation other. Single mentions of a device should be web. The phrases must be commands directed at a system. Do not use for other devices or other ambiguous phrases that could be a shopping or a place search. Note that certain settings have their own intents, e.g. "arm", "lock", etc. Do not annotate "set_device" in those cases. Ambiguous queries that contain the verb "turn" with no particle (on/up/off etc.) should be annotated as set_device.

domains.domainDescription: Requests related to music, radio, video, TV and movie, plus media control, e.g., volume control, fast forward, rewind, repeat and pause.  If the query only has artist (e.g., "adele"), media_title (e.g., "Call me maybe") or media_genre (e.g., "R&B"), and nothing else, it should be Other (web search) domain.  If it is asking for a list of music, it goes to MEDIACONTROL (e.g., "Bollywood romantic songs", "Taylor Swift music"). Any queries starting with "sing" is chitchat, e.g., "sing a song".  If it is a high-confident pattern, such as "play *", "listen to *",  even * doesn't match music entities, please be aggressive to tag play_media intent, as long as * is not clearly something else, e.g., "play a trick", "play Google", "play UPS".

domains.domainDescription: Reminder domain is about creating, editing, and finding Reminders. Since creating reminders can be easily confused with creating calendar events and note taking, it is very important that the intent to create a reminder is unambiguous.

positiveExamples.query: Can you remind me to do something?
Remind me to wake up at 7 am
Remind me to water plants every 2 days at 8 AM
Remind me to go to gym every weekday
Remind me to buy fresh fruits every Monday, Wednesday and Friday
Remind me to trek to Mt. Everest every 5 years
Remind me to buy milk when I'm at Whole Foods
Can you help me remember to find the principal when I get to Luca's school
Remind me to pay my parking ticket when I'm downtown
I want to remember to call Maura when I'm at Pike and 3rd
Remind me to water plants at home every Monday
I want to set a repeating reminder for Josh's soccer lessons
Every time I talk to my wife remind me to tell her she is beautiful
Every time I get home, remind me to walk the dog
The insurance premium payment reminder is due by 1st Jan

intents.description:
The user asks to create a reminder. Below are usual scenarios: 
1. The user can start by just stating 'set a reminder'. Then Cortana asks for reminder subject followed by trigger which could be either time or location. 
2. The user sets a reminder by only specify the subject. Then the flow gets into multi turn to get triggers - time or location.  
3. The user creates a time reminder by specifying either time, date, subject or a combination of them. If the specified time is more than current time, the current date is defaulted otherwise. If any parameter is missing, the flow gets into multi-turn to get all parameters. User can also specify the recurrence from following patterns: every day, every 2 days, every weekday, every week, every 2 weeks, every month, every 4 months, every year, every 5 years and every Monday, Wednesday and Friday.
4. The user can create a location reminder by specifying the location at which it should trigger. For each location, user should be able to set Arrive/Leave option. User sets a reminder for a location present in the 'frequent places' section of notebook. This section will contain all the hubs (major - home/work and minor - gym) as well as explicitly saved locations. User sets a reminder for a generic location by speaking the common name - such as Starbucks. A generic location is one that is not saved. For such cases, the scenario defaults to a search using the generic location as the keyword. As an extension location reminder at a generic location, we should support high precision (and high recall) for common, know POIs using their canonical names. This scenario should not lead to disambiguation.
5. When setting a reminder for due date, the query should be specific to a reminder.

positiveExamples.query: Move my picture day reminder up 30 minutes

intents.description: The user asks to change an already-existing reminder.

intents.description: The user asks to find an already-existing reminder.
user asks to delete an already-existing reminder

user asks to dismiss, cancel or turn off an already existing reminder. We support following patterns. (a) All: cancel all upcoming reminders. (b) Time: support time patterns like a particular time (e.g. 9 PM), today, tomorrow, Monday, next Thursday, next week, 31st Dec, this month.  (c) Location: could be home, office, favorite place, generic place and is the trigger for the reminder. (d) Next: using next keyword, users can turn off the next reminder that is to trigger. (e) This/That/all of these/all of those: users can cancel reminders that they most recently created or recalled.
user asks to snooze a reminder using snooze or other related keywords.

user asks for a note or reminder to be read aloud to them. The user must be clearly in the reminder domain from the previous turn to request reading aloud without specifying reminder (e.g., read it, tell me what it says).
Used for any reminder intent that is clearly reminder domain BUT NOT covered above.

This slot marks the body of the reminder. There are no titles for reminders (it's just a blob of text). 
Reminder text can be broken across a contact name, or very simple. The important thing is that by annotating contact name the reminder will be triggered when communication with that contact occurs. In order for the scenario to work, the contact name must not be included in the reminder text.
